title.narrative: Protection and Humanitarian Assistance Services for Refugees in Uganda

description.narrative: Address the humanitarian needs of South Sudanese refugees in neighbouring countries, strengthening the humanitarian-development nexus and focusing in particular on increasing sustainability and resilience.,Increase the scale, coverage and sustainability of life-saving humanitarian activities in South Sudan in order to strengthen people's and communities' coping strategies, whilst pursuing resilience activities whenever possible.

Uganda's refugee population stands at one of the highest points in its history with 1,064,043 refugees and asylum seekers in country as of 31 January 2017 (population verification ongoing with 825,776 bio-metrically registered and an estimated 238,267 pending bio-metric registration). The majority of these refugees originate from South Sudan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Burundi. During the second half of 2016, the South Sudan refugee emergency situation in Uganda dramatically peaked. The country received the single largest refugee influx from South Sudan with some 489,234 new arrivals and a total of 640,008 South Sudanese refugees by 31 December 2016. An estimated 275,000 South Sudanese refugees are sheltered in Bibibidi settlement in Yumbe District, which was opened on 3 August 2016. This settlement surpassed its maximum carrying capacity and became the largest refugee-hosting settlement in the world; and new settlements, Palorinya and Imvepi were opened. In addition, by the end of 2016, there were approximately 222,641 refugees from DRC and 44,165 refugees from Burundi in Uganda. These figures were reported by the GoU's Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) through the Department of Disaster Preparedness and Refugees, Refugee Information Management System (RIMS), as of December 2016.In the revised planning scenarios of 2017, Uganda may receive over 560,000 new refugees, of which 40,000 will come from DRC; 500,000 from South Sudan, and 20,000 from Burundi (from 10,000 planned for initially). Approximately 79% of the total refugee population in Uganda are women and children. Following the GoU's policy, the refugee response operation should provide support to the host communities living in and around the settlements (an estimated 450,000 persons). Through ECHO funding in 2017, UNHCR plans to provide access to primary health care; water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) services, emergency shelter support, and protection assistance.
